moment you have to have them locally and run with `-f <path_to>/collector-<xxx>/scala`).

$ find . -name \*-all.jar

title: Updates AnormDB and database library versions; Fixes SQLite
body:
This updates all db libraries to latest, and sets the base version of
PostgreSQL to 9.3. It also corrects HikariCP configuration for SQLite,
which prevents it from erroring out on account of JDBC variant mismatch.

AnormDB was using old versions of just about everything, including very
EOL PostgreSQL. More importantly, SQLite stopped working due to a recent
HikariCP change, which moved the default JDBC variant to 4.

Relates to #511

title: Moves zipkin-mongodb to its own repository
body:
zipkin-mongodb was late merged and has little test coverage. The tests
that do run require special travis or laptop configuration to manage a
localhost mongod. The maintenance involved in mongod is not justifiable,
as it isn't likely used by anyone.

This change isolates mongodb to its own repository, where it can either
be maintained, or be archived.

It is an acknowledged reality that this repository won't work until we
release zipkin artifacts it depends on, and perhaps perform other
modularity work.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-mongodb

Commands used to make zipkin-mongodb

``` bash
git clone https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin.git
cd zipkin/
git subtree split -P zipkin-mongodb -b zipkin-mongodb
git checkout zipkin-mongodb
git remote add zipkin-mongodb https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-mongodb.git
git push -f zipkin-mongodb zipkin-mongodb:master
```

has endangered the productivity of the project. Since this has never
been released, this burden isn't justifiable.

be maintained, or be archived.

release zipkin artifacts it depends on, and perhaps perform other
modularity work.

title: Gradle.
body:
### Why?

Because the SBT build is a pain.
### What works
- `./gradlew check` runs tests using [maiflai/gradle-scalatest](https://github.com/maiflai/gradle-scalatest) and they pass.
- `./gradlew build` builds normal jars, and an IDL jar for `zipkin-thrift`.
- `./gradlew distTar` builds a tar distribution for the stand-alone services
- `./gradlew installDist` generates a runnable version of the services (basically the contents of the output of `distTar`)
### What doesn't work

I'd appreciate thoughts on how important these are.
- The `doc` project isn't ported yet. I can take a stab at it, but if someone knows what actually happens there, they'll probably have an easier time.
- `BuildProperties` is not ported. Do we need it?
### What might not work

I'd appreciate experienced eyes on these
- Maybe some tests are not picked up by Gradle
- Maybe some artifacts don't look like they should (especially IDL and standalone service stuff)
### Integration test

I used https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-zipkin/tree/gradle to bring up Zipkin, and sent traces to it using

``` sh
./zipkin-tracegen/build/install/zipkin-tracegen/bin/zipkin-tracegen -scribeDest=$(docker-machine ip):9410
```

And I saw traces :smile: 
### Notes
- The SBT build system is still in place to make comparison easy.

title: Bintray publish settings
body:
### Problem

We need to release artifacts built in travis to Bintray openzipkin/zipkin repo.
### Solution
#### How it works
- user creates a tag `git tag v1.2.3` 
- then does `git push origin master --tags`
- triggers the publish script to be called after travis build is successful
- script creates a bintray credentials file in travis... 
- then using bintray-sbt pushes artifacts to packages/modules in bintray (i.e. openzipkin/zipkin/zipkin-collector-core)
  - based on encrypted values in travis.yml
  - `gem install travis`
  - `travis encrypt BINTRAY_API_KEY=<Bintray API key>--add`
  - `travis encrypt BINTRAY_USER="<Bintray username" --add`
### Caveats
- not detecting if the tagged branch is master due to bug in travis (https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/1675)
- still running tests when tag is pushed, needs workaround
- modules/packages in Openzipkin repo need to be created manually (i.e. zipkin-collector-core) due to https://github.com/softprops/bintray-sbt/issues/58
- current version number in Project.scala
- building from oraclejdk7

title: Ports specs/jmock tests to scalatest/mockito and cleanup
body:
Before, tests were a mix of scalatest and specs, and a mix of jmock and
mockito. This migrates all tests to scalatest/mockito and removes the
`@RunWith` annotation, which isn't necessary in SBT or Intellij.

All tests are now `FunSuite` except `QueryServiceSpec`, which is vast
and better organized as `WordSpec` for now.

Almost all tests use Matchers, and the ones that don't aren't hurting
anything, so could later be moved to Matchers if desireable.

Finally, doing this simplifies the build: we now have a single test
dependency bundle, and it is far simpler than before.

Fixes #493

title: Zoom the trace view based on user selected time range.
body:
Our traces sometimes span across a few minutes. That causes a bunch of spans to get huddled up in a corner. This pull request is to enable users to have a better viewing option in such cases. User can move mouse over the span view to select a time range and entire span view would be zoomed in according to selected time range. User thus gets a better view of the spans they are interested in analyzing.

A zoomout button would pop up which allow users to go back to original view. The button has a fixed position on screen so that even if user scroll up or down the zoomout button is always available at same position on screen.
Please check and let me know your feedback.

Thanks,
Nikhil.

Solution:

cross-platform, using Java's APIs that are supposed
to work across platforms.

PS: I added som println statements to debug; **can anybody
on a Unix box please run "sbt" and see what pops up?**
It's important that it should say that the original resolver
and the cross-platform resolver point to the same URL
on a Unix box!!!!!
I will remove the println statements afterwards.

title: Major refactor of Project.scala
body:
**Note**: this depends on #475 
### What, why

`Project.scala` was over 600 lines of boilerplate-heavy, hard-to-read code. This PR aims to improve the situation by moving what can be moved to `build.sbt` files under each project, and leaving clean, readable, DRY glue-code in `Project.scala`.
### Result

To my eyes, `Project.scala` is now much easier to read. Common code, dependencies and settings are collected and clearly separated from project definitions. The project declarations and the definition of inter-project dependencies are now clearly separated from the configuration of individual projects. The longest `build.sbt` is 29 lines of code, making the build configuration of each project quite approachable and easy to grasp, modify.

I expect this change to make the maintenance of the SBT-based build system much easier, and also to vastly simplify any attempts around migrating to Gradle.
### Testing

To test the changes, I ran `clean`, `compile` and `package` (where applicable) for each project, and compared the log before and after the changes. Also did a full `sbt test` in the end. All this may still mean that some things are broken by the refactor. I'm specifically unclear on how to test, and so unsure of the correctness, of:
- `addConfigsToResourcePathForConfigSpec`, wrt/ evaluation time (I expect it's re-evaluated in the context of each specific project)
- the `DocTest` configuration in the `doc/build.sbt`

I'd highly appreciate a close look at these specifically, and of course at the whole change generally. I did everything that came to mind around testing what I broke, but you know the saying about the number of bugs. Problem classes that may or may not be introduced by this change:
- an artifact is not build
- an artifact doesn't contain what it should / contains stuff it shouldn't
- some tests are not even started
- incomplete / missing generated documentation

title: Deduplicate dependency definitions
body:
This is a first, opinionated stab at DRYing the dependency definitions in `Project.scala`. I aimed to make reading the file and updating dependencies easier. I chose some heuristics to get closer to this goal (this is the opinionated part):
- the version number for an artifact must appear exactly once in the file
- there should be minimal duplication of group ids, artifact ids and classifiers
- a shorter dependency list is easier to read
- a shorter file is easier to read

After the trivial stuff was out of the way, I made three biggish changes:
- Version numbers are not listed separately in stand-alone variables. They **do** appear in exactly one place, usually together with the group and artifact id.
- DRY'd the hadoop and hdfs dependencies similarly to how many others (finagle, util, ...) were already handled
- Instead of `Seq(finagle("core"), finagle("http"))` let's write `many(finagle, "core", "http")`

Take it apart :) I'll happily update the PR, both in the case of better heuristics and better / more idiomatic code.

Room for further improvement, in a separate PR: splitting into per-project `build.sbt` files would remove some boiler-plate, leading to cleaner, more readable, maintainable code. (Is there a reason not to do that?)

`getHostName` in tests. We do that, so pre-emptively cutting the
`-Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true` flag to dodge a potential buffer
overflow.

title: Switch database connection pool from DBCP2 to HikariCP
body:
Switches database connection pool from [Apache Commons DBCP](https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-dbcp/) to [HikariCP](https://github.com/brettwooldridge/HikariCP).

Collector performance testing results can be found [here](https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/444#issuecomment-118163389). DBCP and HikariCP performed approximately the same under heavy load. However in addition to its comparable performance HikariCP has some significant technical advantages that are described in [this recent pull request comment](https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/444#issuecomment-118304025).

title: Removes zipkin-tracer gem as it is now in its own repo under openzipkin
body:
This deletes zipkin-tracer from twitter/zipkin to avoid confusion as to
where the code authoritatively is: openzipkin/zipkin-tracer

zipkin-tracer has been recently maintained by Lookout, who started
openzipkin to facilitate community-driven development. The zipkin-tracer
gem has been imported, retaining history to openzipkin/zipkin-tracer.

Inside openzipkin, there's a "Ruby" team which any former maintainer is
welcome to join. The zipkin-tracer gem will now be properly maintained,
tagged, and released from openzipkin/zipkin-tracer.

title: Removes zipkin-query gem
body:
The zipkin-query gem is out-of-date, untested and full of tech debt
such as TODOs and hard-coded hosts and paths. Internally at Twitter, I
can find no use of it. Its only change was one day after it was written,
over three years ago.

I tried fixing thrifts, regenerating code, etc., but I think it is clear
this effort could be put on more important tasks. Hence, let's remove
the zipkin-query gem.

title: MySQL performance and connectivity improvements
body:
We have identified several improvements for Zipkin deployments that using a MySQL database for storage,
- Automatic reconnect for dropped connections so that the collector and query services do not need to be restarted
- Automatic retry for transient/recoverable exceptions so that web app users and clients sending traces to the collector service are not affected if seamless recovery is possible
- Proper back-pressure for maintaining stability under heavy load conditions instead of unbounded resource (Java heap, native threads) growth
- Database connection pooling for significantly improved collector service performance under heavy load conditions
- Prevent constraint violation errors if duplicate traces are sent
- Document recommended indexes for optimal performance for MySQL deployments
- Query service performance improved significantly for getServiceNames, getSpanNames, getTraceIdsByName, and getTraceIdsByAnnotation - includes both updated SQL and table schema additions
- Add timers for all SQL executions that can be viewed using the admin API

title: Reduce default query limit from 100 to 10
body: We've found that the default of 100 trace results is somewhat excessive, and 10 is more reasonable (and potentially substantially better performing) in most cases. This pull request reduces the default query limit from 100 to 10. One notable downside to this change is that when two or more annotations are specified, the probability of a matching intersection being found can be decreased.

title: Fix java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: empty.min error
body:
This pull request fixes a couple similar exceptions that we've seen when querying for nonexistent annotations.

a)

```
ERR [20150528-17:13:02.755] query: java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: empty.min
ERR [20150528-17:13:02.755] query:     at scala.collection.TraversableOnce$class.min(TraversableOnce.scala:194)
ERR [20150528-17:13:02.755] query:     at scala.collection.immutable.List.min(List.scala:76)
ERR [20150528-17:13:02.755] query:     at com.twitter.zipkin.query.QueryService$$anonfun$getTraceIds$1$$anonfun$apply$9$$anonfun$apply$11$$anonfun$11.apply(QueryService.scala:161)
```

b)

```
ERR [20150625-16:42:41.283] query: java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: empty.min
ERR [20150625-16:42:41.283] query:     at scala.collection.TraversableOnce$class.min(TraversableOnce.scala:194)
ERR [20150625-16:42:41.283] query:     at scala.collection.mutable.ArrayBuffer.min(ArrayBuffer.scala:47)
ERR [20150625-16:42:41.283] query:     at com.twitter.zipkin.query.QueryService$$anonfun$getTraceIds$1$$anonfun$apply$7.apply(QueryService.scala:147)
```

The exceptions can be easily reproduced by searching for a) an annotation that doesn't exist or b) two or more annotations that do not exist.

The openjdk7 build doesn't work and #423 broke the one that worked. This constrains Travis to what can pass, allowing contributors to make use of it as opposed to be constantly distracted by a half-broke build.

In the future, we'll want to fixup the current build and re-add openjdk.

title: Addition of Redis SpanStore + Factory to enable Cake pattern usage
body:
Hi,
I wanted to try out the Redis storage and couldn't find a SpanStore or SpanStoreFactory for it in the codebase. I have added one, including using the SpanStoreValidator tests. Also found a some minor inconsistencies in RedisIndex class when using the SpanStoreValidator to test
- It threw an exception if there were no annotations in the span
- It indexed core annotations which was inconsistent with the Cassandra/AnormDB implementations

Apologies the pull also includes a sample redis-example project based on your zipkin-example I was using to test with which is included in the Project.scala

title: Add web UI for viewing aggregated trace data
body:
There we go - I've cleaned up the code a bit.
Tell me if there are any issues that have to be addressed! (code style etc)

**Commit message**

> After running the zipkin/aggregate hadoop job, dependency
> links are stored in the database. This allows us to draw a
> graph of the entire system.
> 
> Hovering over nodes will highlight which dependency links it has.
> Clicking a node will show a list of its dependency links, and
> from there you can click on a dependency to view data about the
> dependency link itself. (number of calls, mean time etc)
> 
> The width of an arrow corresponds to the amount of traffic
> between nodes (the number of calls made).

title: Include web resource root in packaged web.sh
body: When running zipkin-web/scripts/web.sh from a built distribution (i.e. `${zipkin}/bin/sbt zipkin-web/package-dist`), attempting to access `http://<host>:8080/` currently results in an empty response. This change adds the proper resource root to the web.sh start script per `doc/install.md` and resolves this issue.

title: Show exact time of each annotations at SpanPanel
body: For investigation purpose, we often want to know not only duration but also the exact time of each spans. This patch shows their local date time at Span Panel. This is useful to investigate the cause of  irregularly long span by collating its time with server log file.

title: Feature/hadoop
body:
For context, see https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/zipkin-user/Z89XJfC3goo
The commit messages explain a bit what's going on in the PR. It's basically just a copy of [this Scalding job](https://gist.github.com/bmdhacks/48f1108a5577dbd2fa3a) discussed in https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/zipkin-user/q_EMWaNbHCw/qBCHqgeL3bMJ, with a custom Scalding tap/sink built on top of zipkin-cassandra.

I chose to put the low-level hadoop implementation in zipkin-cassandra, since it's cassandra-specific. That also makes stuff easier if Zipkin is ever ported to the native Cassandra client, since Cassie is deprecated. (see https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/zipkin-user/Ul58F0WZfe4)

For some reason, I had to change some stuff in zipkin-scrooge to make it build with sbt. I'm not quite sure why. I included it in this PR as a separate commit. If one can build 3b1e4bf without a493c0b, then I guess one could drop that one.

The module is currently only built with sbt - it's missing pants BUILD files. Somebody with more pants experience has to add that, I guess.

There will also be a web UI, but I'll provide that as a second PR later on, so the PR doesn't grow too big!

There's a README showing how to set it up. It would be great if people who run Zipkin with Cassandra in production could battle-test this, and reply to the PR!

title: Fix AnormSpanStore#getTracesDuration to get the duration of the entire trace.
body:
SpanStore.getTracesDuration should return the duration of the entire trace. But the current implementation of AnormSpanStore.getTracesDuration returns a span's duration rather than a trace's one. Because of this, QueryService can't sort correctly by duration.

This PR is the same as https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/397, but to `AnormSpanStore` instead of `AnormIndex`.

repo.name: zipkin

title: Add support for sbt-assembly to zipkin-{web,{query,collector}-service}
body:
Since the assembly plugin is already included, I assume this is not very far from the intended purpose. The code is longer than strictly necessary and has some repetition to make sure the change has only minimal impact. This can of course be changed by just adding everything to `defaultSettings`.

The conflicts for which I added the `first` merge strategy:
- `com/twitter/zipkin/query/adjusters/*.class` built for `zipkin-query` and `zipkin-query-core` differed
- `com/twitter/common/args/apt/cmdline.arg.info.txt.1` differs between `com.twitter.common.zookeeper/server-set/jars/server-set-1.0.72.jar` and `com.twitter.common/args/jars/args-0.2.6.jar`
- `commons-beanutils-core` has both versions `1.7.0` and `1.8.0` somewhere in the dependency tree; I didn't track down where exactly.

body: If I understand correctly, `Index.getTracesDuration` should return the duration of the entire trace. But the current implementation of `AnormIndex.getTracesDuration` returns a span's duration rather than a trace's one. Because of this, `QueryService` can't sort correctly by duration.

title: Improve WriteQueueWorkers' pushback
body:
For storage engines that do most of their work under the returned future (such as hbase),
having the WriteQueueWorker return immediately means that the write queue is not an
accurate representation of the amount of outstanding work.

title: New Trace UI
body:
This is a re-write of the main trace UI. I'll get an example up soon.

With this re-write all generation happens server side. Once rendered, we use flight to add behavior to the page. The page is rendered as styled divs instead of via d3. The page will now take up the full width of the browser, popups are also larger and clearer. Individual spans can be expanded and collapsed. Filtering of services has been simplified and expanded as well.

title: account for timezone change
body:
If the data was saved in a different timezone than the one it's being viewed, it will not display correct results.
This change will use the ISO 8601 format, which the timeago jquery library knows how to handle.
